Title: The Politics of Climate Change Loss and Damage (CCLAD)

This project, situated at the intersection of International Relations and climate change policy, investigates the emergence and contestation of justice norms in the context of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The urgent need to address climate change consequences has led to a lack of consensus on loss and damage policy, with significant implications for disaster risk reduction, non-economic losses, finance, and climate-related migration. Through an interdisciplinary theoretical and ethnographic approach, CCLAD will explore the micro-politics of international negotiations and domestic policy practices, comparing the latter across different countries.

The project's objectives are threefold: to understand the conditions for norm hegemony, to examine the influence, contestation, or reversal of norms, and to develop a new understanding of norm-content fluidity. Building on the theory that norms are partly constituted through policy-making and implementation, CCLAD will make methodological contributions to political ethnography and develop practice-tracing methods. By shedding light on the dynamics of norm emergence and contestation in the context of climate change loss and damage, this project will inform more effective and just policy responses to this critical global challenge.
